greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of parts in all the compositions of n into primes (i.e., in all ordered sequences of primes having sum n).
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 2..2000
example: a(8) = 17 because the compositions of 8 into primes are [3,5], [5,3], [2,3,3], [3,2,3], [3,3,2] and [2,2,2,2], having a total of 2+2+3+3+3+4 = 17 parts.
maple: seq(a(n), n=2..50);  # _Alois P. Heinz_, Nov 08 2013, revised Feb 12 2021
mathematica: Table[Length[Flatten[Union[Flatten[Permutations/@Select[ IntegerPartitions[ n], AllTrue[ #,PrimeQ]&],1]]]],{n,2,40}] (* The program uses the AllTrue function from Mathematica version 10 *) (* _Harvey P. Dale_, Oct 24 2016 *)
results.author: _Emeric Deutsch_, Aug 06 2006
